scenes.voiceover_script: Ever feel like the next 'big investment' is just a trap? From meme coins to overhyped startups, millions of people lose money chasing returns that were never real. The uncomfortable truth? Most of these 'assets' were designed to take your money from day one.

Real money isn't just paper or code. Throughout history, currencies had value because they were backed by something—gold, government power, or productive assets. When governments mint money, the difference between production cost and face value is called seigniorage. It's a hidden tax we all pay.

Here's the danger: when bad money floods the market, good money disappears. This is Gresham's Law. People hoard real assets and spend worthless ones. If you can't tell the difference, you end up holding the bag when the music stops—and it always stops.

If you're chasing triple-digit returns in meme coins or unproven startups, ask yourself: am I the investor or the exit liquidity? Whenever something looks too good to be true, someone is probably getting rich—and it's not you.

Before you invest, check these four essentials. One: Is it backed by real power or authority? Two: Does it have hard collateral? Three: Does it generate actual profit? Four: Can you pay taxes with it? If none of these apply, it's probably not money—it's a gamble.
